body:
Hi @criccomini,
Can you provide some more context here? It seems to me that it is possible for counts to be 0 for a period of time. I agree that the ratios in general should reflect indeterminate status, but I am wondering if it makes sense here. Why doesn't None work for you here? 

```
for m in self.metrics_sorted:
            if current[m] == 0 or reference[m] == 0:
                ratio = None
            else:
                ratio = float(max(current[m], reference[m])) / \
                    min(current[m], reference[m])
            logging.info(rlog.format(m, ratio, self.metrics_thresholds[m]))
```

+1.

In general, db connections should be pooled for all usage. Some databases, e.g. Oracle, cannot handle constant db connection turnover - it results in fragmentation on the db side.  Not sure how viable that is here, but just wanted to share that thought.

I'm not sure it is reloaded everywhere. For runtime and dynamic config, it's better to use Variables. 

Can you describe your use case and why Variables won't be a good fit?
If you can find and fix the bug, I'd be happy to review a PR.
Need to change the dags_folder variable.
@mistercrunch I revised the code to be under 80 chars per line.  PTAL.
Closing. PR was committed.
I don't really have a strong preference either way, but pid files do have the pitfall of becoming stale, so your context manager approach sounded sane to me.

The implementation (with a ContextManager) I did was uses TimedPIDLockFile no negate the issues of stale lock files. It checks if the PID actually is there that is recorded in the lock file. 

The older behavior is still available with "-f" or "--foreground" but the issues with LocalExecutors not dying have been solved here as well (multiprocess daemon=True).

I would definitely test it. Please note that the systemd files still need to be updated for these changes.

If configuration is reloaded it is reflected everywhere. This was implemented a couple of months ago to allow testing for different authentication backends. Of course if a dag or somethings else has already been instantiated and a configuration item is localized (ie, self.my_item = configuration.get("item") ) then this will not get updated.
Yea, I guess the problem that I had was that the table was empty, which wasn't expected. But I think that can be taken care of with a regular CheckOperator, so I'm going to close this.
LGTM

@bolkedebruin This is good to know. Then there is a case like this in the jobs.py script, which specified a default for heartrate in the `__init__` method. This would not be updated correct?

```
    def __init__(
            self,
            executor=executors.DEFAULT_EXECUTOR,
            heartrate=conf.getfloat('scheduler', 'JOB_HEARTBEAT_SEC'),
            *args, **kwargs):
```
Which version of airflow are you using (can you just print `git log | head`)? Do you also see this behavior when running in the UI or via the CLI with LocalExecutor (i.e. specify `-l`)?

Also, can you confirm that you are not seeing anything under `http://<your_airlfow_webserver>:8080/admin/taskinstance/?flt1_pool_equals=<your_pool_name>` -- Note: replace the 2 placeholders above. Share a screen shot here.

Airflow version is 1.6.2, I installed via `pip`, not via `git`.  

If I run with LocalExecutor it works and populates the pool page, otherwise it just looks like this:
http://imgur.com/5sjlpSr
Absolutely correct.

Thanks for https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/1013 

I happened to find and verify the same fix, so I know yours works. I'll await the requisite coverage tests to pass before merging. Thanks for the fix.

The more I think about this the more it seems that the necessity for workers to communicate with the database for heartbeats, is a scalability constraint. If you maintain a connection pool on each worker then you potentially need thousands of db connections just to maintain heartbeat. Why not have workers stick their updates into a queue that the server reads from? Why not have kill messages delivered via queue based events as well? None of these operations require transactionality that it would be worth to pay the scalability cost for.
LGTM
@mistercrunch will revisit this in a week or so when I have time.
what if you backfill or clear something in the past? timeouts are better when measured against the start time than the run time.

Here is what I have found. I have a modified piece of code (modified from what @kretes) provided. Here is the code : ``` from datetime import datetime, timedelta from airflow import DAG from airflow.operators import BashOperator, DummyOperator dag = DAG("MYDAG_5", default_args={"owner" : "me", "start_date":datetime.now()}, schedule_interval='*/1 * * * *', dagrun_timeout=timedelta(minutes=4) ) def command(): return "echo {{ params.myparam }} {{ (execution_date).strftime('%Y/%m/%d %H %M') }} 2>&1 >> /tmp/logs" run_this_last = DummyOperator(task_id='run_this_last', dag=dag) firstTask = BashOperator( task_id='first', bash_command=command(), params= {"myparam":"1"}, dag=dag) secondTask = BashOperator( task_id='second', bash_command=command(), params= {"myparam":"2"}, dag=dag) firstTask.set_downstream(secondTask) secondTask.set_downstream(run_this_last) ``` I loaded this new DAG around `02-17T03:22:47.319562` When the DAG starts, it fails due to the DAGRUN_TIMEOUT! Looking at the DAG run view, I see the following : As you can see, it has failed almost immediately after starting. Each and every run fails! Looking at the DAG run table, I see the following : It looks like the problem is that the start date is set 8 hours behind the execution date! I loaded the DAG `02-17T03:22:47.319562` and my schedule is minutely, but the start_dates are set to '2016-02-16 19:23:02.289377', which is 8 hours behind the current datetime and also behind the execution_date. I am running everything in UTC, except the database! My database is running in PST. ``` sid-as-mbp:r39132_airflow siddharth$ !psql psql -h localhost -U siddharth airflow psql (9.4.1) Type "help" for help. airflow=# select CURRENT_TIMESTAMP; now ------------------------------ 2016-02-16 19:34:40.06475-08 (1 row) ``` So, it looks like start_date is set based on the DB TZ, while the execution_date is set using TZ where airflow is executing

I've confirmed and fixed this. Our stage and prod envs are on UTC, but my laptop used to be on PST. It's now also on GMT/UTC, and now so is my local postgresql instance. After changing my DB TZ and restarting scheduler and webserver, it works.

@kretes I suspect this is also happening to you. Closing for now. If this is not the issue, then ping me to reopen.

If you use Postgres 9.4, you can change the TZ by
`airflow=# ALTER DATABASE airflow  SET timezone TO 'Etc/GMT';`
The logout of the DB and relogin:

```
airflow=# select CURRENT_TIMESTAMP;
              now              
-------------------------------
 2016-02-17 03:59:46.934656+00
(1 row)
```
@martingrayson Can you provide a stack trace as well as the version that you are on (e.g. You can provide a `git log | head` snippet)!

I just tried to reproduce this. I am running on current master head. I am running Local Executor on my Mac Laptop against a local PostgreSQL DB, everything on UTC. My Target DAG has a once schedule: ``` from airflow.operators import * from airflow.models import DAG from datetime import date, datetime, time, timedelta args = { 'start_date': datetime.now(), 'owner': 'airflow', } dag = DAG( dag_id='simple_dummy_once_dag_v1', default_args=args, schedule_interval='@once') run_this = DummyOperator( task_id='run_this', dag=dag) ``` I execute the following command 2 times to create to DAG runs: ``` sid-as-mbp:dags siddharth$ airflow trigger_dag simple_dummy_once_dag_v1 [2016-02-17 04:36:49,089] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor LocalExecutor [2016-02-17 04:36:49,666] {cli.py:101} INFO - Created ``` I start with all of my DAGs disabled (which is a config parameter): Here are the 2 DAG Runs ready to run (in running, but not actually running since the DAG is disabled): I now enable `simple_dummy_once_dag_v1`. And 3 jobs succeed, 1 scheduled (for once) and 2 triggered:
I also triggered this one more time while the DAG was enabled. It all works fine for me. Pending some further details from you, I am closing this. If you are still seeing this, `@` me on gitter.

Hi @jasminetsai!
I had a similar request to pass parameters via `airflow run/test/backfill` commands. It would be great if you could tackle this problem -- I'd be happy to review a PR.

The airflow worker is a thin wrapper around the celery worker command and doesn't do much more than running the `airflow run` commands it receives from the queue. `airflow run` commands are executed as subprocesses and are the ones getting the connection count up.

From my perspective, the short term solution is to alter the sqlalchemy behavior when running `airflow run` to not maintain a pool. At every heartbeat (every minute, but configuraable), a connection would be created and destroyed.

Another longer term solution would be to go through a REST api call. I would prefer that over the message queue idea since only in the case of the CeleryExecutor we have the assumption that there is a message queue to be used.
removed the bug tag as this is more of a scalability issue than a bug

@mistercrunch has been allowing Google hook/operator commits without tests because 1) they're in contrib and 2) we're the only known people using them.

We do have "add tests" on the list of things to do, but it's kind of non-trivial right now due to the dependency on google cloud storage and bigquery.
Sorry for the noisy PR, the refactor ended up touching a lot of files.
Thanks for working on this Maxime. I'm currently running a massive job which will likely only finish by the end of the week. I should be able to test then.
:+1:  thanks for the PR!
This won't show up under `airflow.hooks` unless you add it to `airflow/hooks/__init__.py`

The reason why this happens is because the operator is looking for `.sh` extensions and trying to resolve those relative to you pipeline (.py) file. You cannot use full paths when using this feature (handled by jinja). When you add a space, it reverts to thinking that the string is the content of a bash command (as opposed to a reference to a file) and then just runs it.
Someone should clarify this in the docs.

I guess this error happens because dags_folder contains '/' at the end of the folder, try to remove '/' at the end of config. example:

wrong: /home/user/airflow/dags/
right: /home/user/airflow/dags

Thanks for the explaination. It seems like not very intuitive behavior for the end user since python scripts use the full path, but shell scripts should use relative paths to the dag file as I understand it?
Agreed. Starting with Airflow I feel the software itself isn't helping you go with the best practice and it is easy to configure something in a way that is not working correctly

From my point of view having an implicit requirement of run in UTC, and introducing weird bugs when it is not running like that instead of 'forcing' this as this is internal DB configuration is a bug.
I see https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1015 is tracked so hopefully it will be solved

@r39132: Thanks again for the response. I will update the documentation. Do you have any example how can I pass information from a dag to a triggered dag? How I get the information on the triggered dag?
@Rulevoid how did you getting the payload on the triggered dag?

Hi! 
Good question and the answer is that it is not exposed currently in any useful way to allow setting it : https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/operators/dagrun_operator.py#L46

I don't think it is needed for most use-cases. What I think you are actually looking for is a way to pass state to your python callable. Here's how:

```
from airflow import DAG, utils
from airflow.operators import *
from datetime import date, datetime, time, timedelta


def foo(context, dag_run_obj):
    print "INSIDE FOO = {}".format(context['params']['passed_by_me'])
    if True:
        return dag_run_obj

dag = DAG(dag_id='test_trigger_dag_run_for_Sid_1',
          default_args={"owner" : "me",
                        "start_date":datetime.now()},
          schedule_interval='*/1 * * * *')

trigger = TriggerDagRunOperator(task_id='test_trigger_dagrun',
                                trigger_dag_id="simple_dummy_dag_v1",
                                python_callable=foo,
                                params={'passed_by_me':1},
                                dag=dag)

```

If you want to pass some state to the python callable via the TriggerDagRunOperator, just follow the example above.
Excuse me if I am being presumptuous about your needs. I will close this for now, but if you need something else, you can ping me gitter.
FYI, I have provided an example of passing state to the Python callable in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1029

Good question. Reopening questions and I now understand the other issue that you opened. Post the question on gitter - I know @nicktrav is doing something with triggering subdags. That might hold a solution. I'll investigate as well later tonight,
Agreed. It's a bug. We are looking for contributors as well, so feel free to pick issues off the list.
Also, we need to make running in UTC an explicit requirement until we can fix the code to not care.
Yes, we need to clarify this behavior in the docs. Renaming this issue.

A quick explanation:
BaseOperator defines a `template_ext` class attribute that goes along with `template_fields`. 

`template_fields` is a tuple of instance attributes (that match the constructor kwargs by convention) that are "templated" and for which we should apply the jinja2 magic.

`template_ext` is a tuple of file extensions as in `('.hql', '.sql')` that if found as endswith in the `template_fields`, should be resolved and as a file to get the file's content. For example in the `HiveOperator`, the `hql` attribute is templated and `.hql` files will get resolved by Jinja. You have the choice to pass an HQL string, or a reference to a file.

For BashOperator it's more confusing since things like `bash myscript.sh` will result in a TemplateNotFound error. Adding a space a the end bypasses BaseOperator trying to resolve the file.

Note that the files are resolved relative to where the pipeline file lives. You can also add other folders to the `template_searchpath` as you create the DAG object.
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.models.DAG

The magic takes place at some point between the `__init__` and the `execute` methods of the operator, and is handled by the framework

Check out the `template_searchpath` attribute of the DAG object.
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.models.DAG

You can also pass sql as a string to the operator.

Another shortcut option is `airflow.utils.readfile` which doesn't do much but is a clean shortcut that will take a fullpath.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/utils.py#L414

Related notes and answers:
- The desired behavior is to listen only to the specified queue(s), if no queue is specified the default queue should be used 
- We use redis as the broker at Airbnb and use queues extensively, it works very well for us, but haven't tested on RabbitMQ
- Workaround idea, what about not using the `default` queue, ever?

If you think think that you can send a PR that will fix this behavior we'll be happy to review it.

I'm guessing that the issue is around the fact that your start_date isn't a proper schedule and that you're using `depends_on_past=True`. 

In short, `depends_on_past` is only disregarded where execution_date==start_date. So if you switch the start_date to 2am, or your schedule to midnight things should align properly.
Reopening with new title

Let's keep the conversation in a single issue. Let's keep the conversation in #1029 I'll change that title to be the same as this one  'Help using TriggerDagRunOperator'

@r39132: the problem with the backfill issue is solved, aligning the start_date and the intervale_schedule by setting the start_date to 2 AM solved it. I then did the backfill with success from -s "2016-01-01 02:00" -e "2016-02-19 02:00"

I left the DAG ON (as shown by the web interface), with the following configuration:

```
default_args = {
    'owner': 'airflow',
    'depends_on_past': True,
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 1, 1, 2, 0),
    'retries': 1,
    'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=5),
}

dag = DAG('dummy', default_args=default_args, schedule_interval='0 2 * * *')
```

The problem is that the DAG should have ran again today at 2 AM with execution date 2016-02-20, and it didn't. All the previous tasks from 2016-01-01 up to 2016-02-19 completed successfully.

The current date on the server is: Sat Feb 20 19:19:58 UTC 2016
Version: Airflow 1.6.1 on Linux with UTC everywhere
Architecture: running on a single-machine

The dag run for the execution date 2016-02-20 wouldn't run until 2016-02-21 at 2 am.

So the behaviour is actually expected as far as I know.

@davidsbatista 

So, this is something that may need better documentation. Airflow was developed as a solution for ETL needs. In the ETL world, you typically summarize data. So, if I wanted to summarize data for `2016-02-19`, I would do it at `2016-02-20 midnight GMT`, which would be right after all data for `2016-02-19` was available.

When you did a backfill, you probably did `airflow backfill dummy -s 2016-01-01 -e 2016-02-19` -- these are inclusive data boundaries. Hence, the `2016-02-19` data was already generated by your backfill and there was nothing for the scheduler to do when you re-enabled it. 

Now, once `2016-02-20` completes, you should see it get summarized. Hence `2016-02-20` will run on `2016-02-21T02:00:00Z`,which is UTC 2am on Feb 21. 

This is what @DinoCow was also saying, I just went into a little more detail. Does this make sense? 

If you wanted to also test this theory, you could have `airflow backfill dummy -s 2016-01-01 -e 2016-02-18` and then turned on your DAG to watch the scheduler execute `2016-02-19`.

Thank you for both replies. Indeed that was exactly what happend. I agree that with you @r39132, that needs to be better documented. You can add that first sentence somewhere in the documentation.

Plus, this line in the FAQ is somehow missleading:

> Is your start_date set properly? The Airflow scheduler triggers the task soon after the start_date + scheduler_interval is passed.

soon after the start_date + scheduler is rather subjective, I think adding an example, e.g., something like the sentence you wrote on your comment would make this much more clear.

Thank you once again for all the feedback.

From: http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/scheduler.html
"""
Note that if you run a DAG on a schedule_interval of one day, the run stamped 2016-01-01 will be trigger soon after 2016-01-01T23:59. In other words, the job instance is started once the period it covers has ended.
"""

A related use-case is to trigger a dag-run from the command line, with a particular configuration.  We have achieved this by copying the creation of a DagRun object of the TriggerDagRunOpeartor, into a stand-alone python script.  

Would it make sense to expose the creation of DagRun's in some method?

The code I have had to copy is:

```
def CreateDagRun(args):

    dict_args = vars(args)
    session = settings.Session()
    dr = DagRun(
        dag_id=args.dag_id,
        run_id=args.run_id,
        conf=dict_args,
        external_trigger=True)
    logging.info("Created DagRun {} with parameters: {}".format(dr, dict_args))
    session.add(dr)
    session.commit()
    session.close()
```

where `args` is an `argpase` derived set of objects.  Some thought should be given to how the arguments are exposed.
Glad to have you with us!
Excellent!
